conclusion: Determine the heat transferred to the gas from state A to B to C on the p-V diagram.
State A: p_A = 1.0 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 6.0 x 10^-2 m³; State B: p_B = 2.0 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 6.0 x 10^-2 m³; State C: p_C = 3.0 x 10^5 Pa, V_C = 4.0 x 10^-2 m³.
Temperature at state A: T_A = 27°C = 300 K.
From A to B is a constant volume (isochoric process).
From B to C is a linear path on the p-V diagram.
Calculate temperature at state B: T_B = T_A * (p_B/p_A) = 600 K.
Calculate temperature at state C: T_C = T_A * (p_C * V_C)/(p_A * V_A) = 600 K.
Work done from A to B is zero (constant volume).
Work done from B to C: W = 5000 J = 5.0 x 10^3 J.
Change in internal energy (ΔU) is zero since temperatures at B and C are the same.
Heat transfer (Q) calculation: Q = ΔU + W = 5.0 x 10^3 J.
The heat transferred to the gas is 5.0 x 10^3 J.
